DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Against Georgia-Pacific in Takeover Battle
Eds: EDITS throughout to UPDATE with comment, tighten; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday rejected a request by Georgia-Pacific Corp. to move up a meeting of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. shareholders to consider a $3.8 billion takeover offer. U.S. District Judge Gene Carter said he did not want to cut off debate prematurely in the merger battle and rejected Georgia-Pacific's motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction. ``This discussion is of great concern to the public, and the public's interest as well as that of the shareholders is served by letting the discussion mature,'' Carter said. ``... harm may accrue to Great Northern and the public if the deal is rushed to completion and it is then determined that the newly formed corporation is in violation of the antitrust laws,'' the judge said. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific asked Carter on Thursday to move the Great Northern shareholders meeting from March 20 to within 30 days, saying it wants shareholders to have a quick say in the rival paper maker's merger offer. Georgia-Pacific also sought to force Norwalk, Conn.-based Great Northern to provide it and the court with 72 hours notice of any financial restructuring that could make the $63-a-share tender offer less attractive. Great Northern already has agreed to provide Georgia-Pacific with information on any changes it makes, and Georgia-Pacific could challenge any changes if it thinks they are improper, Carter's ruling said. Georgia-Pacific on Friday extended its offer through Jan. 5 and said 73 percent of Great Northern's shares had been tendered. It said it was disappointed with the ruling. Great Northern spokesman Stephen Hill called ruling ``wonderful.'' Carter has not yet ruled on another Georgia-Pacific motion seeking to set aside part of the ``poison pill'' provisions in Great Northern's bylaws intended to thwart a hostile takeover. Hill said the deal would violate antitrust laws, an issue to be decided in a federal trial scheduled to begin Wednesday in Bridgeport, Conn., in a lawsuit brought by Great Northern. The ruling Friday came in motions filed in a separate lawsuit challenging Great Northern's poison pill and Maine's antitakeover law. The Federal Trade Commission in Washington had faced a Thursday deadline for deciding whether it believed the proposed merger would run afoul of antitrust laws, but an FTC spokeswoman said no announcement was planned. Georgia-Pacific said the deadline passed without any action by the FTC, ``satisfying one of the material conditions to Georgia-Pacific's offer.''
